ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

GOVERNMENT SECONDARY
SCHOOLS IN BUKIT HO SWEE


    1. Madam Chan Choy Siong asked the Minister for Education when will Government secondary schools be built in the Bukit Ho Swee area.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, a building tender has recently been accepted for the construction of a secondary academic school and a secondary vocational school within the Bukit Ho Swee area.

    The secondary academic school comprises 26 class-rooms, two special rooms, four Science laboratories, three domestic Science rooms, one hall, one canteen and one library room. The total cost is estimated at $1 million.

    The secondary vocational school comprises 18 class-rooms, three special rooms, two Science laboratories, four domestic Science rooms, one hall, one metal workshop block, one wood-workshop block and one library room. The total cost is estimated at $800,000.

    These two secondary schools will be completed by December next year and will start functioning at the commence ment of the 1966 school year. They will provide an additional 3,800 secondary school places.

VETERINARY CENTRE IN
PUNGGOL


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether and when a Veterinary Centre will be built in the Punggol Constituency.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, action is in progress to acquire a piece of land at the 9 m.s. Punggol Road for the construction of a veterinary clinic and extension centre. At the same time, detailed planning for the centre is being undertaken by the P.W.D. and it is expected that the centre in Punggol will be completed in 1965.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): May I know from the Minister for National Development what is the size of land to be acquired and what will be the total cost of the proposed veterinary centre?

Column: 331



    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the land is about one-third of an acre and it is estimated to cost about $11,000. The centre is estimated to cost $60,350.

ELECTRICITY SUPPLY IN
PUNGGOL


    3. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether and when electricity will be supplied from 9 milestone Punggol Road to Punggol Point.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon): Mr Speaker, Sir, I answer on behalf of my Minister.

    Mr Speaker: Will the hon. Member please resume his seat?

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon resumed his seat.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, if it is in order, my Parliamentary Secretary will reply on my behalf.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Ho Cheng Choon, please proceed.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon: The Urban and Rural Services Consultative Committee has drawn up a scheme for the supply of electricity by the Public Utilities Board to the whole of Punggol area. The scheme covers the following areas:

    Lorong Buang Kok

    Kampong Sungei Tengah

    Jalan Kampong Tengah

    Kampong Serangoon Kechil, and

    Punggol Road, 9¾ m.s. to seafront.

Some of these areas have already been supplied with electricity. The stretch of Punggol Road from 9¾ m.s. to the sea-front will be supplied with electricity as soon as the sub-station in constructed. Action has already been taken by the Public Utilities Board to acquire the site for the sub-station and when construction is completed, electricity mains will be laid and advertised to supply electricity to houses wanting to have connections.

Column: 332



    Mr Ng Kah Ting: What is the total cost of this electrification scheme and is there any subsidy granted by the Government?

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon: The total cost of this scheme will be $272,190. The revenue over a period of seven years from the areas benefitting is estimated to be about $255,484 and a subsidy of $16,000, or $42 per house, has been paid by the Government to enable the scheme to be implemented.

ROAD

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for National Development): Electricity supplies can be made available in the areas around 11 milestone Yio Chu Kang Road as soon as a sub-station is constructed, equipped, and commissioned.

    A site was previously allocated for a sub-station, but due to objections from the Toa Mong Public School authorities, it is now necessary to negotiate for an alternative site.

WIDENING AND METALLING OF
LORONG BUANG KOK


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development when will Lorong Buang Kok, which is a link to Yio Chu Kang Road, be widened and metalled.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, Lorong Buang Kok is about two miles long. The cost of widening and metalling this road will be very high and there are more urgent claims to the limited funds available for such development. In view of this high cost, the Urban and Rural Services Consultative Committee has deferred the proposal to metal this road which has, however, been made up to agricultural road standards.

REPAIR OF AGRICULTURAL
ROADS AT 9½ AND 11 M.S.
YIO CHU KANG ROAD


    6. Mr Tan Cheng Tong asked the Minister for National Development when will the following unmetalled agricultural roads be repaired: (a) two of the four roads linking Boh Sua Tian Road at 9½ milestone Yio Chu Kang Road to Sungei Seletar Fishing Village; (b) Track 23 between 9½ milestone Yio Chu Kang Road and Cheng San Road; (c) upper Tong Lee Road between Jalan Kayu and Boh Sua Tian Road; and (d) Track 22 at 11 milestone Yio Chu Kang Road.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for National Development): The answer to (a) - one proposal for the making up of one track from Boh Sua Tian resettlement area leading to Sungei Seletar has been received by the Urban and Rural Services Consultative Committee from the members of the Citizens Consultative Committee of the area, while another proposal for the making up of Boh Sua Tian Road leading to the seaside Malay kampong has been received by the Prime Minister during his recent tour of the area. Both these proposals are being considered by the Urban and Rural Services Consultative Com mittee and, if approved, construction work will commence within the next few months.

    The answer to (b) - a proposal for the making up of Track 23 between 9½ milestone Yio Chu Kang Road and Cheng San Road has been received from the people of the area. It has been deferred by the Urban and Rural Services Consultative Committee on account of

Column: 334

the high cost. This track is a long one and the area is not sufficiently developed to justify the expense involved.

    The answer to (c) - the repair of this road is not on the priority list for repair of agricultural roads and no request has been received so far for this repair. The Work Brigade will, however, be asked to look into the possibility of repairing this road prior to consideration by the Urban and Rural Services Consultative Committee.

    The answer to (d) - a proposal to make up Track 22 at 11 milestone Yio Chu Kang Road using quarry weights will be considered by the Urban and Rural Services Committee and, if approved, construction work will commence within the next few months.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong (Jalan Kayu)(In Mandarin): On (c), I would like to put a supplementary question.

    The Parliamentary Secretary has just now said that nobody has made any application to repair this road, but I would like to point out to him that when I was in the P.A.P. I had already mentioned it, and especially when the Prime Minister was touring that area.

BUS-STOP SHELTERS IN RURAL
AREAS


    7. Mr Tan Cheng Tong asked the Minister for National Development whether the Government has any plan to build in the rural areas more bus-stop shelters at places where there are no shops or houses.

It is the normal practice to give favourable consideration to requests for bus-shelters in places

HOME FOR THE AGED IN
WOODLANDS
(Compensation for families affected in scheme)


    8. Mr Ong Lian Teng asked the Minister for National Development how many families were affected adversely by the building of a Home for the Aged in Woodlands and how many of these families did not receive compensation from the Government.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, four families altogether are affected by the building of the proposed Home for the Aged in Woodlands. All of them will be paid compensation in accord ance with the schedule of approved rates. Assessments of compensation have just been completed and payment of compensation will be made in the near future.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have just said that assessments of compensation are just being made. I believe the hon. Member has asked me whether I am aware that one of the families affected has not received compensation. None of them has received compensation. Assessments of compensation are being made, and when the time comes, they will be paid compensation.

CHILDREN'S PLAYGROUNDS IN BUKIT HO SWEE ESTATE AND
OTHER HOUSING BOARD
ESTATES


    9. Madam Chan Choy Siong asked the Minister for National Development whether and when children's playgrounds are to be provided in Bukit Ho Swee Estate and other Housing Board Estates.

Column: 336



    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is already in existence a large children's playground constructed by the Housing and Development Board adjacent to the school and clinic in Bukit Ho Swee Estate. This children's playground of about three-quarters of an acre in area is equipped with swings, seesaws, a paddling pool, a climbing tower, concrete play-blocks, etc. Two additional children's playgrounds are being constructed in the Nile Road and Beo Crescent Estates adjacent to Bukit Ho Swee. These two playgrounds will be completed in about a month's time.

    Generally, there is at least one children's playground provided in every large housing estate in addition to other social amenities, such as badminton courts, community centres, etc. Wherever necessary, additional children's playgrounds will be provided in new estates.

PUBLIC ASSISTANCE
(1-6-64 - 30-9-64)


    10. Mr Ong Lian Teng asked the Minister for Social Affairs between 1st June, 1964, and 30th September, 1964, (a) how many of the people who were in receipt of public assistance had had their assistance stopped; (b) how many had had their assistance reduced; and (c) what was the total amount involved in each case.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, because of the increasing expenditure on public assistance and of reports received that a large number of public assistance recipients had not been reporting on their true family circumstances and were thus continuing to draw public assistance although they were, in fact, not eligible, it was decided early this year to conduct a systematic review of all public assistance cases.

    Between 1st June, 1964, and 30th September, 1964, a total of 5,982 public assistance cases were reviewed and, as a result,

    (a) 1,112 cases had their public assistance payments stopped;

    (b) 1,285 cases had their public assistance payments reduced;

    I should also like to add that the annual expenditure on public assistance has been steadily rising from year to year.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [2nd November, 1964], "That the Assembly approves the financial policy of the Government for the year 1965.". - [The Minister for Finance]

    Question again proposed.

2.52 p.m.

    Mr Speaker: For the convenience of Members, I wish to make one or two observations so that the debate might be assisted and proceed without much difficulty. I should like to inform Members that they will confine their debate to the general principles of Government policy and administration as set forth by the Minister for Finance in moving the motion and as indicated in the main Estimates. Any detailed discussion of the Estimates will take place tomorrow and the day after that. Today, Members will please confine themselves to the general principles of Government policy and administration. For the benefit of the Members of the Opposition, I draw their attention to Standing Order No. 82, paragraph (4) which reads:

    'Thirty minutes before the end of the time permitted on the allotted day, the Speaker shall, if the debate shall not previously have been concluded, call upon the Minister who moved the motion to reply.'

So Members of the Opposition will so adjust their speeches that they will give the Floor to the Minister for Finance at 7.30 p.m.

Column: 339



    Mr Chia Thye Poh (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance has already given his Budget Statement in this House. No matter how much stress he has laid upon economy, the fact is that his Budget Statement is invariably made in accordance with the desire of the Party in power to deal with the present situation. This is a point known to anybody who has some common sense in politics. This statement is used as a means of publicity whereby those things in which the Government can take pride are highlighted in the speech. Those things that are annoying or are not so glorious will be mentioned less and less, or even not mentioned at all. Therefore, in the past, such talk about the increase in the national income, the rate of progress, prosperity and so on, has taken up a lot of space in the speech of the Minister for Finance. But the statement this year shows that his tone is beginning to change. Although he has made a great effort to say that there is still economic stability in the State, he has to admit, whether he likes it or not, that the P.A.P. Government has to meet for the first time a deficit. The so-called $15 million surplus is no longer in existence. It is time for the Government, as it says, to think carefully.

    Mr Speaker, those who have talked so well of Malaysia have tried their best to describe it as a small New York; that Malaysia is successful and so on. Just as a mirror reflects the true image of things, let us look at the facts. There is a great deal of misery among the people. It is impossible for the Party in power to cover up the ugly facts.

    Mr Speaker, I now wish to talk about the effects of confrontation on our economy. Singapore has all along depended on the entrepot trade economically. As a result of the Indonesian confrontation, there are great repercussions, according to the Minister himself. The Indonesian confrontation is, however, not 100 per cent successful. There are still a lot of raw materials coming from a third country into Singapore. That accounts for the not

Column: 340

so great decline in our trade. The so-called not 100 per cent successful confrontation, in spite of what the Minister says, has brought great losses in our trade. According to his figures. for the first half-year, there was a decline of 31 per cent in our export trade. In respect of imports, the decline was 23 per cent. In the meantime, about 4,000 people are out of job. The Minister has also said that the increase in banking and building construction activities has, to some extent, reduced the effect of Indonesian confrontation. We do not wish to over-estimate the effects of the Indonesian confrontation. But we have to face it all the same.

    The Minister for Finance, in spite of what he says, has not been able to sketch to us the full extent of the Indonesian confrontation affecting our economy. I will tell him that directly or indirectly the effect of it is very great on the trade and livelihood of the people. Under normal circumstances, trade should increase instead of decrease. But now the fact is that our trade is on the decline. The Minister tries to say that the decline is only to the extent of 23 per cent in respect of imports and 31 per cent in respect of exports. He says that only about 4,000 persons are out of job as a result of confrontation, but this figure only includes those directly affected by the confrontation. This figure does not include those who have been indirectly affected. The Minister should know that, at the present moment, shops at large have not been doing so well in their business. Hawkers and retailers are suffering from a trade recession. Their income has decreased considerably. Why is it that the Minister has made no mention of these facts? He himself says that there are some trades which have been affected by confrontation, such as the entertainment business and so on. If the people have to worry about their meals, do you think they can afford to worry about entertainment? At night the shops in the amusement parks are not doing any business at all. So under-employment and under-nutrition have put a lot of poor people and

Column: 341

small traders in difficulties. So faced with the difficulties and disasters brought about by the Indonesian confrontation, it is useless to try to put the blame of our failure on Indonesia and try to find a scapegoat.

    The pro-Malaysian Parties are duty bound to solve these problems. Before the problem of Malaysia is solved politically, the Government should find ways and means to assist the lightermen and others who are directly or indirectly affected by this stoppage of barter trade and other trades. Those businessmen engaged in the barter trade should be given assistance. But the Government has not tried to shoulder part of the responsibility. At the present moment, it is trying to depend too much on the building construction trade to try to cancel off some of the effects of confrontation. But there will come a time when the building construction trade will reach saturation point: then there will be thousands of workers engaged in this trade who will be thrown out of work.

    The important point is that our present economic difficulties should be solved basically. The economic solution is closely connected with the political solution of the Malaysian dispute. Without the support and sympathy of the Afro-Asian countries, and without the sustained support of the people, Malaysia will not be able to stay in existence for a long time.

    Mr Speaker, I wish to go on to the question of industrialisation and the common market. The P.A.P. Government at present is attaching great importance to the success of industrialisation in order to try to solve the mounting unemployment problem, and to make use of industrialisation as a means to console the people who are directly or indirectly affected and afflicted by Indonesian confrontation. At the present moment, the 47 factories which are said to have gone into production are able to employ some 2,000 workers. Even when they go into full production, the maximum number of workers employed will be only about 6,600. During the five years of its rule, the P.A.P. Government

Column: 342

has been talking about industrialisation. The Minister for Finance has given great publicity to the opening of factories from time to time. But, in spite of all the great show put up, the employment opportunities created by this grand opening amount to only 4,000. This is only a small percentage of the unemployed people. According to the Minister himself, there are about 30,000 youths coming into the labour market every year. Up to the present moment, there are at least thousands and thousands of youths unemployed. If you add to this figure those who have become unemployed after confrontation, then the figure is far too great to be solved. The Minister has not told us of the contribution made by the new industries to our national income, whether they are able to cancel off the loss of 8.7 per cent of the national income brought about by confrontation, and whether they are able to maintain only - and not to increase, I stress - the present national income. On the other hand, the financial powers have largely been transferred to the Central Government. Even the approval for certificates of pioneer status is controlled by the Central Government. The Federation itself is also faced with the problem of unemployment. It has also got to find a way to solve it. So do you think the Federation Government will grant pioneer status to Singapore industrialists? I would like to ask: after Malaysia, how many factories in Singapore have been awarded pioneer status by the Federation Government? Under these circumstances, Mr Speaker, how can you expect a lot of employment opportunities to be created?

    The present investment in industries has been taken up mainly by foreign capital - British, American and Japanese. These countries have invested considerabl7 in our industries. They have made large profits too. I do not know whether the Government has taken any steps to make sure that the profits de rived from local industrialisation will be ploughed back into further investment in our own country and not sent out. If you allow foreign capitalists to invest by means of their worn-out machinery

Column: 343

in conjunction with local capital, derived from the hard-earned efforts of our own people, thereby resulting in a great flow of capital outwards, then can you say that foreign capital investment is of advantage to us'? The P.A.P. Government is always good at propaganda and showing oft. If in these problems the Government is only good at showing off, and nothing more than that, then I will say that our economic future is rather bleak. We try to attract foreign capital to our local industrialisation. We go to foreign capitalists for loans at interest. But, on the other hand, we invest our own money, to the extent of some $300 million or more, in foreign countries, much to their benefit. I suggest that the P.A.P. Government would do better to invest such funds in our own industries. It hopes that by the establishment of the common market, local industry can be developed. There is a list declared of 101 items of goods to be included in the common market. But has the Gov ernment noticed that various measures, particularly in the field of tariff, have been formulated under pressure of foreign monopolists and capitalists? These measures will invariably lead to a rise in the price of consumer goods. So in the public interest, I would say that the common market is a means by which foreign capitalists and monopolists try to strengthen their own position in Singapore. The success of such industrialisation will only lead to a higher cost of living within the next three to five years. People will suffer all the more. I must also point out here that the interests of the workers should not be sacrificed to those of the foreign capitalists. The so-called collective bargaining is carried out in favour of the capitalists. So foreign capitalists will be able to exploit with ease the workers of our own country and make more profits.

    I shall now go on to the question of the budget deficit. According to the Estimates, there appears for the first time a deficit in Singapore to the extent of $20 million. According to the Minister himself, this is because of increasing expenditure in the first place; and, in the second place, the necessity to pay to the Central Government to meet the cost

Column: 344

of public services and national defence. No matter under what circumstances the deficit has come about, and whatever economic activities are carried out to sustain public services, it is a waste of public funds to build things such as the National Theatre, swimming pools and playgrounds. People are not able to clothe and feed themselves. So how can we expect them to stroll in the parks'? It is a waste of money to build houses if people are not able to live in them. Many houses built by the Housing and Development Board have been left vacant. It is not that the people do not want to live in such houses, but because of the increased expenditure. To the lower income group, this increased expenditure is beyond their means.

    Next year, because of Malaysia's arrangements, Singapore has to contribute 40 per cent of its revenue to the Central Government, amounting to $120 million. On the other hand, we have to lend about $30 million to North Borneo, thus resulting in a deficit. This sum of money is not going to be used on social welfare for the people of Malaya but on defence. Even on the loan to North Borneo, the Minister has said that the Government will not just hand out this sum of money. But up to now, how many workers have been recruited from Singapore by the Borneo Government? Therefore, the Minister will be quite foolish to give the loan. The main sources of revenue, such as income tax, customs, duty on tobacco and petrol and road tax, are all State revenue. If there is any change in the rates of duty, Singapore will be affected directly because of the Alliance Government's military expansion. The Federation Government's reserve funds have gone down. Therefore, they may increase the rate of taxation, and the burden on the Singapore people will be increased accordingly. Not only has Malaysia brought about unemployment, but because of the continuation of the war in North Borneo, the people in Singapore have to meet the rising cost of living.
